title: Verb Conjugation
explanation: Japanese verbs change their forms (conjugate) and are divided into three groups. Depending on the conjugation, verbs can express various meanings.

title: Verb Groups
explanation: Verbs are divided into three groups depending on their conjugation patterns.

title: Verb て-form
explanation: The て-form ends with て or で. It is made differently depending on the verb group. Group I depends on the last sound of the ます-form (いきます → いって is an exception). Group II attaches て. Group III also attaches て.

title: Vて-form ください ( Please do... )
explanation: Used to ask, instruct, or encourage the listener to do something. Cannot be used to give orders to a superior. Adding すみませんが makes it more polite.

examples.japanese: すみませんが、この漢字の読み方を教えてください。
examples.english: Excuse me, could you tell me how to read this kanji, please?

examples.japanese: ここに住所と名前を書いてください。
examples.english: Please write your name and address here.

examples.japanese: ぜひ遊びに来てください。

title: Vて-form います ( be V-ing )
explanation: Indicates that an action is in progress (be V-ing).

examples.japanese: ミラーさんは今電話をかけています。
examples.english: Mr. Miller is making a phone call now.

examples.japanese: 今雨が降っていますか。

answers.japanese: いいえ、降っていません。

title: Vます-form ましょうか ( Shall I do...? )
explanation: Used when the speaker offers to do something for the listener. The listener may accept politely, decline politely, or ask for clarification.

dialogue.japanese: あしたも来ましょうか。
ええ、10時に来てください。

dialogue.english: Shall I lend you an umbrella?

dialogue.japanese: 荷物を持ちましょうか。

title: S1が、S2 ( ... but ... )
explanation: が as a conjunctive particle can mean 'but,' but in polite expressions like 失礼ですが or すみませんが, it serves as an introductory remark.

examples.english: Excuse me, but may I have your name?

examples.japanese: すみませんが、塩を取ってください。

title: Nが V (Natural Phenomena)
explanation: When describing natural phenomena, the subject is marked with が.
